*[Bug 18912] New: Missing unit suffix (pt) in SVG dimensions causes rendering issues in PowerPoint*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18912>

            Bug ID: 18912
           Summary: Missing unit suffix (pt) in SVG dimensions causes
                    rendering issues in PowerPoint
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.4.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Graphics
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:abhishek.x.bablani@gsk.com|abhishek.x.bablani@gsk.com>

Description
In R version 4.4.2 and later, the svg() graphics device produces files with
width and height attributes in the <svg> tag without any unit suffix (e.g.,
"pt"), whereas in previous versions (e.g., 4.4.1), the suffix "pt" was
included.

This omission causes PowerPoint and other tools to assume the default unit is
pixels (px) rather than points (pt), which results in the graphics rendering at
approximately 75% of the intended size (due to the px/pt difference: 96 DPI vs
72 DPI).

Impact
Incorrect rendering of SVGs in PowerPoint and other tools that rely on explicit
unit definitions.

Output appears smaller than expected (e.g., 7x5 inch plot shows up as
~5.25x3.75 inches).

Manual editing or post-processing is currently required to restore correct
rendering.

Expected Behavior
The svg() device should retain the "pt" suffix for width and height attributes
to preserve compatibility with tools expecting properly defined dimensions.

Environment
Affected R versions: 4.4.2, 4.4.3

Unaffected R version: 4.4.1

Operating Systems: Windows (confirmed), likely cross-platform

Packages: Base R graphics (no additional packages required to reproduce)

Suggested Fix
Ensure that the SVG output explicitly includes pt

*[Bug 18912] Missing unit suffix (pt) in SVG dimensions causes rendering issues in PowerPoint*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18912>

Peter Dalgaard (<mailto:pd.mes@cbs.dk|pd.mes@cbs.dk>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
                 CC|                            |pd.mes@cbs.dk

--- Comment #1 from Peter Dalgaard (<mailto:pd.mes@cbs.dk|pd.mes@cbs.dk>) ---
This seems to be happening in current R as well. A simple test SVG comes out
starting with

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="504" height="504" viewBox="0
0 504 504">

whereas graphics/man/figures/pch.svg has 

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="504pt" height="50pt"
viewBox="0 0 504 50" version="1.1">

This is really Paul Murrell turf (i.e., I don't really have a clue what is
going on), but on the looks of it, I expect that we may need a call to 

cairo_svg_surface_set_document_unit ()

at some point close to opening the device.

(and no, I do not know what we did last Summer... There is no record of us
changing anything SVG related for 4.4.2. It may have come from the underlying
libraries.)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz

--- Comment #2 from Paul Murrell (<mailto:paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz|paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz>) ---
This looks like a possible culprit ...

```
Change the default SVG unit to user unit
```

... in <https://www.cairographics.org/news/cairo-1.17.8/>, which is also a
plausible seeming Cairo version for the observed impact on R (at least on
Windows).

The `grSoftVersion()` function could be used to check Cairo versions on
different R versions.

Peter's suggested fix sounds good, but will need testing to ensure that it does
produce "old" R behaviour.  On the bright side, as SVG is just text, that
testing might only need to consist of a `diff`.
